This species was sporadically detected in Helgoland as attached individuals already by Kuckuck (Herbarium specimen XXXX), but a permanent population only started around 1969 in the south harbour and continually expanded to other sheltered areas along the coast of Helgoland.

taxon_text_17_61: The main thallus consists of long strap-like fronds with a single ovoid bladder centrally interspersed at intervalls. The axis is flattenend except round at the base. Thallus is greenish-olive to olive brown in colour, with a discoid holdfast developing several upright fronds with few dichotomous laterals positionend at margins which are identical to, but shorter than main primary axis . Many of the secondary laterals are shorter than the first ones.

taxon_text_17_133: Brown to olive brown thalli of one or more long, unbranched strings arise from a small disc -shaped holdfast . Strings are cartilaginous and mucilaginous to the touch and circular and mostly hollow in cross section. Thalli are covered by translucent hairs when young. With age, the thalli lose the hairs and may be overgrown by epiphytes. Strings generally grow in clusters, float below the water surface and become intertwined.
taxon_text_17_140: The solitary thallus consists of a terete , firm, whip-like frond circular in cross-section and about 1 mm thick, attached by a small discoid holdfast . The surface of the thallus is characteristically slippery due to the outer layer of short filaments. Numerous side branches of similar thickness develop at a wide angle up to second order , giving young individuals a bottle-brush like appearance, whereas in older individuals the branches in the upper part of the thallus grow characteristically much longer than the main axis . Abundant colourless true hairs are present. In a mature stage the alga appears dark-brown to black, while young ones still show a light brown colour. The cortex consists of radiating filaments of rows of 7 - 10 chromatophore-carrying cells ending in a spherical cell. Filaments separate easily when squashed. The medulla consists of elongated cells oriented along the direction of the axis . Unilocular sporangia are pyriform to elongate, 60-100 µm long, and 20-28 µm in diameter.
taxon_text_17_362: The thallus is brownish-green with a single monopodial axis with wide, flattened frond irregularly dichotomously to laterally branched. The midrib is distinct and has acute serrated margins. Holdfast is discoid and conical.
taxon_text_18_135: Fertile from July. A closed layer of elliptical unilocular sporangia and elongated club-shaped paraphyses covers the entire thallus except the base.
taxon_text_18_142:
The alga shows a direct or a heteromorphic life history with no sexual reproduction. Unilocular sporangia are pyriform to elongate, 60-100 µm long, and 20-28 µmin in diameter. They appear from May onwards.

Towards winter, microthalli might develop instead of the usual cycling of the upright thalli , perhaps as a means for surviving until next spring/summer.

taxon_text_17_2802:
As the group of endophytic brown algae is hard to distinguish, we only give a short summary here. For details see further reading below.

Endophytic brown algae may appear as minute dark spots, scattered patches to dense felts on host algae . The infection by endophytes may cause other symptoms in hosts, such as holes on infected blade tips, twisted stipes or necrotic and distorted blades. Sometimes the infection may not be obvious to the naked eye.

Usually, thalli consist of an endophytic part of microscopic uniseriate , branched filaments. In some taxa only phaeophycean hairs emerge from the host surface, other taxa show epiphytic filaments up to 1 cm in length.

In german marine habitats the group includes i.a. Laminariocolax aecidoides, L. atlanticus, L. tomentosoides and Laminarionema elsbetiae.
taxon_text_17_2813: In german marine habitats the group includes i.a. Pseudoralfsia verrucosa, Pseudolithoderma extensum, Petroderma maculiforme, the crust phase of Cutleria multifida and several crusts of the family Scytosiphonaceae.

not allowing the passage of light; not t: not allowing the passage of light; not transparent. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
resembling the genus acrochaetium, a mic: resembling the genus acrochaetium, a microscopic , filamentous , branched or unbranched (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
slender or thread-like, uniseriate to mu: slender or thread-like, uniseriate to multiseriate . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
that part of the thallus other than the: that part of the thallus other than the attachment. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
the female reproductive organ(s), each c: the female reproductive organ(s), each containing one or more eggs. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the living contents of a cell, consistin: the living contents of a cell, consisting of cytoplasm and nucleus. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the main, usually long, branches arising: the main, usually long, branches arising from the top of the stipe . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the opening of a cystocarp in some red a: the opening of a cystocarp in some red algae through which its spores are discharged. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a duplicate of a lectotype, q.v. (source: a duplicate of a lectotype , q.v. (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
attached or fused to another structure;: attached or fused to another structure; pertaining to unlike parts that grow together. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
branches appear on 2 sides of a stalk, a: branches appear on 2 sides of a stalk, alternating at different levels along the axis . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
developing from the apex toward the base: developing from the apex toward the base the youngest structures are nearest the base. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
sexual reproduction with the antheridia: sexual reproduction with the antheridia maturing before the oogonia . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the sporangia of the endophytic shell-bo: the sporangia of the endophytic shell-boring "conchocelis " that produces conchospores. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
with conical or tapering outline (source: with conical or tapering outline (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
with male and female gametangia on the s: with male and female gametangia on the same thallus . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
within a filament (not terminal) (source: within a filament (not terminal ) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a sharp, usually moderately elongate, te: a sharp, usually moderately elongate, terminal or lateral projection. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
an organism in which the vegetative stag: an organism in which the vegetative stage is haploid and the zygote divides by meiosis . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
arranged on one side only (e.g. branchle: arranged on one side only (e.g. branchlets, fig. 2b). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
compact tissue formed by cell division i: compact tissue formed by cell division in all planes. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
simple division of a unicell into two pa: simple division of a unicell into two parts/unicells. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
the orderly recognition of organisms acc: the orderly recognition of organisms according to their presumed natural relationships. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an air-filled vesicle that serves for fl: an air-filled vesicle that serves for flotation as found in sargassum (see air bladder ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
any surface upon which plant grows (sour: any surface upon which plant grows (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
having two layers; cf. unistratose (sour: having two layers; cf. unistratose (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
small pore between adjacent cells, occlu: small pore between adjacent cells, occluded by a plug . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
the common name for the seagrass zostera: the common name for the seagrass zostera marina, a marine and estuarine flowering plant. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p>dense irregularly alternate or unilat: dense irregularly alternate or unilateral or radial branching ; secondary branches short, distinctly  recurved in gametophytes; life cycle stages not recorded for GNS
a lateral, usually irregularly positione: a lateral , usually irregularly positioned, short structure on an organ. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
an elongate structure with an axis beari: an elongate structure with an axis bearing sessile reproductive organs. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
egg-shaped, but broadest near the upper: egg -shaped, but broadest near the upper end (a three-dimensional term). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
extending throughout the entire length o: extending throughout the entire length of a structure; usually said of a persistent axis . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p><strong>plurilocs short and stout</st: plurilocs short and stout, with unilocs on same thallus , often  in the middle of the filament , sessile or on  few-celled stalks
a pit formed between 2 mature cells of c: a pit formed between 2 mature cells of contiguous filaments (cf. primary pit connections ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
filament bearing the female gametangium,: filament bearing the female gametangium , the carpogonium (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
filaments in advanced red algae that ari: filaments in advanced red algae that arise after fertilization and produce carposporangia. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
having two poles each with development i: having two poles each with development in one direction. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
individually distinct; cf. confluent (so: individually distinct; cf. confluent (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
inversely conical, with a contraction to: inversely conical, with a contraction towards the point. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
made of a horn or horn-like substance, s: made of a horn or horn-like substance, similar to that of horns or hooves of some mammals. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
with laterals or their residues arranged: with laterals or their residues arranged like a ladder with cross rungs. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p>branching opposite, at wide angle (45: branching opposite, at wide angle (45°-90°); pattern changes with fertility: laterals inserted unilaterally on the upper side of side branches, alternating with zoidangia
<p>size of medulla and cortex cells more: size of medulla and cortex cells more or less equal; cortex : rel. smaller, pigmented cells; medulla: colourless, large, thick walled cells
Fan-shaped, deeply divided blade becomi: Fan-shaped, deeply divided blade becoming evenly dichotomous towards tip; blunt finely dissected wedge-shaped apices with tufts of hair -like filaments, giving a frayed appearance
intergenic spacer within the plastid gen: intergenic spacer within the plastid genome; see rubisco . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
pressed together without being united (s: pressed together without being united (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the central tissue of a crustose alga th: the central tissue of a crustose alga that is produced inwardly by an intercalary meristem . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a herbarium specimen kept as documentati: a herbarium specimen kept as documentation for an identification reported in the literature. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a modified lateral branchlet usually wit: a modified lateral branchlet usually with reproductive organs in its axil . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a nonmotile spore produced from and sepa: a nonmotile spore produced from and separate from its vegetative mother cell (see akinetes). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a sexual cell capable of uniting with an: a sexual cell capable of uniting with another sexual cell. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a specialised initial cell formed during: a specialised initial cell formed during the development of a conceptacle . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a taxonomic group between class and fami: a taxonomic group between class and family , with the name ending in -ales. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
linked together like a string of beads (: linked together like a string of beads (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the submicroscopic structure of cells as: the submicroscopic structure of cells as shown in the electron microscope. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
trailing on the substratum; lying closel: trailing on the substratum ; lying closely along a surface. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
with branching more or less one-sided or: with branching more or less one-sided or with unequal forks ( e.g., deer-like antler horns). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an enlarged internal hyaline cell in cru: an enlarged internal hyaline cell in crustose coralline algae (i.e., heterocyst , trichocyst ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
binding, obligatory; limited to one mode: binding, obligatory; limited to one mode of life or action. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
having an affinity for fatty substances: having an affinity for fatty substances (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
shaped like a solid disc that is flat an: shaped like a solid disc that is flat and roughly circular. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
shaped like an ellipse; oval with regula: shaped like an ellipse; oval with regularly rounded ends (in 2 dimensions). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
stain used to show up nuclei and other c: stain used to show up nuclei and other cellular structures. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
structure only partly-formed and apparen: structure only partly-formed and apparently non-functional. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
taxonomic latin term \"of authors\"; use: taxonomic latin term "of authors"; used in conjunction with nec or non for a misapplied name. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p><strong>intercalary</strong> <strong>: intercalary unilocs but mostly in terminal rows, partially tapering into long hair -like pointed end cell; plurilocs uncommon
<p><strong>plurilocs with obviously larg: plurilocs with obviously large chambers, unilocs and monopsorangia rare, all sessile or on short 1-celled stalks, in wide angle to axis
branching with no consistent pattern; al: branching with no consistent pattern; also cells not being the same type throughout or having variable shapes and dimensions (cf. irregularly branched) (source: Algaebase (2021-05)).
one branch of a whorl or pair of branche: one branch of a whorl or pair of branches of limited growth . (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
sexual reproduction in which a small, us: sexual reproduction in which a small, usually motile sperm fuses with a larger non-motile egg . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the place (e.g. rock, sand, mud or a hos: the place (e.g. rock, sand, mud or a host ) to which an organism is attached. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the sum of an organism's morphological,: the sum of an organism's morphological, cytological and reproductive phases. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p><strong>fasciculate </strong>(=name g: fasciculate (=name giving: clusters of branches arise near same area on axis ), resulting in a slightly structured appearance becoming more pronounced in summer
<p><strong>robust </strong>bushy thallus: robust bushy thallus with more or less distinct main axis ; colour of axes and side branches dark brown; fresh outgrowths in spring light brown
cells (filament) produced during the for: cells (filament ) produced during the formation of procarps in some red algae (e.g. paraphyses ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
genetically and sexually distinct specie: genetically and sexually distinct species that cannot be recognized on the basis of morphology . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
knob-like outgrowth from crustose thallu: knob-like outgrowth from crustose thallus (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
meiosis resulting in direct formation of: meiosis resulting in direct formation of gametes in a diplontic life history . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
thalli with a core of parallel filaments: thalli with a core of parallel filaments, with each filament being derived from an apical cell . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
curved backwards and forwards like a sin: curved backwards and forwards like a sine wave (e.g. fig. 5c). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
forming dense tufts, with free filaments: forming dense tufts, with free filaments above, similar to those of elachista. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
growing on animal substrata such as shel: growing on animal substrata such as shells (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the alternation of a haploid sexual game: the alternation of a haploid sexual gamete -producing phase with a diploid spore -producing phase. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
unbranched (e.g. of spermatangial system: unbranched (e.g. of spermatangial systems) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
<p>rhizoidal filaments <strong>closely a: rhizoidal filaments closely appressed ; originating from outer cells of main axis forming a compact and thick cortication of main filaments; no cortication at tip
a chamber of a reproductive organ, conta: a chamber of a reproductive organ, containing usually a single gamete or spore . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a cytoplasmic strand connecting two adja: a cytoplasmic strand connecting two adjacent cells through a pit in their wall . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a group of organisms, at any level, in t: a group of organisms, at any level, in the classification of plants or animals. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a reproductive organ that contains a sin: a reproductive organ that contains a single locule (cell) and produces unispores through meiosis . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
branching by outgrowth of small peripher: branching by outgrowth of small peripheral cells on the axes (in cladostephus). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
internal space within the cytoplasm, whi: internal space within the cytoplasm , which is bounded by a membrane and normally contains fluids. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
restriction of the distribution of a tax: restriction of the distribution of a taxon to a particular geographical region. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the cell subtending a carpogonium and ca: the cell subtending a carpogonium and carrying the egg nucleus in the red algal order ceramiales. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p>plurilocs uniseriate to multiseriate,: plurilocs uniseriate to multiseriate , sessile or on short stalks in ~90° angle to axis or terminal on side branches; unilocs (on pro-phases) with few zoids with distinct eye-spot
a perennial taxon that exists in a reduc: a perennial taxon that exists in a reduced or altered state during unfavorable periods for growth . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a taxonomic term describing the category: a taxonomic term describing the category of taxa intermediate between phylum (division ) and order . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
central tissue or central filaments that: central tissue or central filaments that generally run parallel to the surface (see also medulla ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
in charophyceae, a female reproductive s: in charophyceae, a female reproductive structure including an oogonium and outer protective cells. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
in some red algae, a vegetative cell bor: in some red algae , a vegetative cell born on a supporting cell that becomes part of a fusion cell . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
prostrate and more or less disc-like; co: prostrate and more or less disc -like; contrasting with trichoid . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
stratum of aligned vegetative cells (fig: stratum of aligned vegetative cells (fig.12) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
to be fixed into a surrounding mass or s: to be fixed into a surrounding mass or surrounded tightly or firmly (i.e., enveloped or enclosed). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a dense layer of short upright shoots ar: a dense layer of short upright shoots arising from prostrate bases, as in a lawn. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
composed of single cell layer; cf. bistr: composed of single cell layer; cf. bistratose (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
division of a tetrasporangium where the: division of a tetrasporangium where the first and second cleavages are perpendicular to each other. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
in red algae, specialized branchlets of: in red algae , specialized branchlets of distinctive shape that bear spermatangia or tetrasporangia. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
one of the two phases (gametophyte or sp: one of the two phases (gametophyte or sporophyte ) in the life history of a plant. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
partially parasitic but with the parasit: partially parasitic but with the parasite largely independent and photosynthetic. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
sporangia producing mitospores which re-: sporangia producing mitospores which re-cycle the same phase of the life history . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
with the secondary segments of branches: with the secondary segments of branches not increasing in size (sphacelariaceae). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p><strong>Small </strong>(&lt;2-3 cm) u: Small (<2-3 cm) uniseriate or parenchymatous thalli , mostly unbranched, often epiphytic , some with basal cushion produced by radiating filaments
a diploid phase (sporophyte) in a life h: a diploid phase (sporophyte ) in a life history of a red alga that usually bears haploid tetraspores. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an enlarged internal hyaline cell in cru: an enlarged internal hyaline cell in crustose coralline algae ; also called a heterocyst or megacell . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
growing partly within a plant, e.g. chor: growing partly within a plant, e.g. choreonema (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
having a tubular, non-septate multinucle: having a tubular , non-septate multinucleate thallus , such as in the green algae bryopsis and codium. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
rudimentary trichogyne (see womersley 19: rudimentary trichogyne (see womersley 1994, griffin et al. 1999) . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
vesicle-like globules in cells of most b: vesicle -like globules in cells of most brown algae , containing phenolic compounds. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
with small, slightly overlapping thallus: with small, slightly overlapping thallus lobes (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
<p><strong>egg-shaped</strong> to lanceo: egg -shaped to lanceolate , sessile , seldom on 1-2 celled stalks, mostly opposite, sometimes in dense clusters,  arranged in series or whorl -like
<p>with <strong>broad base</strong>, <st: with broad base, cone-shaped, sessile , adaxial side by side in a series giving a saw-blade appearance (characteristic for species !)
a taxonomic category usually differentia: a taxonomic category usually differentiated by a very minor character; the lowest taxonomic category. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a taxonomic group of one or more related: a taxonomic group of one or more related species , separable from other such groups. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
on the side or face next to the main axi: on the side or face next to the main axis of a branch ; towards the axis on the upper side of a branch (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
phylogenetic grouping of genera at a lev: phylogenetic grouping of genera at a level below that of subfamily. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
<p>unilocs <strong>sessile or on unicell: unilocs sessile or on unicellular stalk, in groups of 2 or 4; plurilocs solitary or in small groups on short stalks
a filament with cells divided periclinal: a filament with cells divided periclinally to form two or more rows. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a row of cells joined by primary pit con: a row of cells joined by primary pit connections (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a sporangial covering or a membranous co: a sporangial covering or a membranous covering of superficial reproductive structures (see involucre ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a taxonomic term for the acceptance of o: a taxonomic term for the acceptance of one of 2 competing names that are otherwise equally acceptable. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
darkly pigmented cells in members of the: darkly pigmented cells in members of the spacelariaceae; their presence is a useful taxonomic feature. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
growth of axes or branches by enlargemen: growth of axes or branches by enlargement of medullary cells (e.g. cladostephaceae). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
in some red algae, an axial cell that is: in some red algae , an axial cell that is surrounded by a ring of pericentral cells of the same length. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
non-living rigid structure surrounding t: non-living rigid structure surrounding the plasma membrane of cells. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
plant cell with cell wall removed; the l: plant cell with cell wall removed; the living component of the cell. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
<p><strong>&nbsp;2-3 </strong>times <str: 2-3 times alternate (to pseudo-opposite) branches, ultimate branchlets ending in characteristic short spines (from May onwards)
becoming diploid, usually by fusion of t: becoming diploid , usually by fusion of two haploid gametes (syngamy ). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
containing lobed, branched, or finger-li: containing lobed, branched, or finger-like extensions of a cell that can attach to adjacent structures. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
growing on the surface of a plant; cf. e: growing on the surface of a plant; cf. endophytic (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
name sometimes used for erect filaments: name sometimes used for erect filaments or cortex (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
sterile filaments, usually uniseriate, o: sterile filaments , usually uniseriate , on the thallus surface or within conceptacles. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p>unilocs and plurilocs on short specia: unilocs and plurilocs on short specialized mostly unbranched side branches, arising from  rhizoidal cortex of main axis (may produce a dense felt around main axis )
a prostrate or creeping axis, lying on t: a prostrate or creeping axis , lying on the substrate , from which erect branches arise. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a taxonomic group having origin in sever: a taxonomic group having origin in several different lines of descent. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
in members of the bangiales a single cel: in members of the bangiales a single celled sporangium (i.e., a mother cell) that produces archeospores. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
in the bangiales, spores produced by the: in the bangiales, spores produced by the blade phase where the ploidy level and development are unknown. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
large (usually elongate) multinucleate c: large (usually elongate) multinucleate cells, without cross walls in vegetative parts. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
name sometimes used for basal filaments: name sometimes used for basal filaments or medulla (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
thallus texture smooth and shiny; cf. gr: thallus texture smooth and shiny; cf. grainy , matt (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the ability of organisms to exhibit two: the ability of organisms to exhibit two or more different forms in their life history . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the haploid gametophytic tissue of a cys: the haploid gametophytic tissue of a cystocarp that surrounds the diploid gonimoblast in some red algae . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p><strong>sublittoral</strong>, mostly: sublittoral , mostly epiphytic on diverse seaweeds (esp. on Laminaria digitata blades from spring onwards) or on other substrates
a haploid or diploid microthallic phase: a haploid or diploid microthallic phase capable of asexual multiplication by zoospores. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a seaweed that grows on/in unconsolidate: a seaweed that grows on/in unconsolidated sediment or grows on rocky substrata impacted by sand scouring. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
almost triangular in face view, but with: almost triangular in face view, but with a small bulge in the middle of the upper side. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
morphology resulting from combined effec: morphology resulting from combined effects of genotype and environment. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
organisms whose cells have distinct memb: organisms whose cells have distinct membrane-bounded nuclei or chloroplasts (in contrast to procaryotic). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
rows of adjacent cells with end walls at: rows of adjacent cells with end walls at same level (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
small swollen cells sometimes lining the: small swollen cells sometimes lining the pore canal (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
thallus in which basal filaments are not: thallus in which basal filaments are not contiguous (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the portion of an algal filament that pr: the portion of an algal filament that produces gametes; also, a structure in which gametangia are formed. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the system of nomenclature of binary nam: the system of nomenclature of binary names used for genera and species ; names published after 1 may 1775. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
when the diploid phase is prominent and: when the diploid phase is prominent and the haploid phase consists only of the gametes. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
with areas of distribution that coincide: with areas of distribution that coincide or overlap (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
with separate multicellular diploid (spo: with separate multicellular diploid (sporophyte ) and haploid (gametophyte ) generations. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p>Thallus <strong>feather- </strong>or: Thallus feather- or bottlebrush-like or small tufts; multiseriate ; conspicuous large, dark apical cell
<p>rhizoidal filaments <strong>loosely a: rhizoidal filaments loosely appressed ; originating from cells below laterals or from lowest lateral cells, thus exclusively present in plane of branching
a pit formed between 2 successive cells: a pit formed between 2 successive cells in a filament during cell division (cf. secondary pit connection ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a row of superficial (epidermal) cells t: a row of superficial (epidermal) cells that provide for increased girth by active division (laminariales). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a sporangium with spores indefinite in n: a sporangium with spores indefinite in number in a distinct envelope formed by mitotic division of a cell. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
derived from a common ancestor plus all: derived from a common ancestor plus all and only all of its descendants. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
growth where the apex of an axis is disp: growth where the apex of an axis is displaced by a subtending lateral branch and becomes a pseudo lateral . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
in charophyceae, a male reproductive str: in charophyceae, a male reproductive structure (antheridium ) that includes both sterile and fertile cells. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
linear arrangement of four spores in tet: linear arrangement of four spores in tetrasporangium (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
reproducing asexually, without karyogamy: reproducing asexually, without karyogamy and meiosis (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
resembling conchocelis but without pit c: resembling conchocelis but without pit connections or fertile cell rows. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
<p>plurilocs or unilocs <strong>intercal: plurilocs or unilocs intercalary to terminal , in rows often up to 20 (character of the genus !),  both slightly broader than filament
a general term for algal morphologies th: a general term for algal morphologies that lack a true embryo phase and are non-vascular (see cryptogamic ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a spore formed in a monosporangium (see: a spore formed in a monosporangium (see also lenticular monospore above). (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
having male and female organs in the sam: having male and female organs in the same conceptacle (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
phase of life history, either haploid or: phase of life history , either haploid or diploid , which bears gametangia . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
the inner part of the cortex, differing: the inner part of the cortex , differing somewhat from the cortex (e.g. in chordariaceae). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
with branches arranged in 2 rows on oppo: with branches arranged in 2 rows on opposite sides of an axis ; also in pairs or alternating like a feather. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p>plurilocs <strong>sessile </strong>or: plurilocs sessile or on short stalks, adaxial on side branches, often in clusters of many producing a rectangular or fan-shaped appearance
<p>with <strong>broad</strong> <strong>b: with broad base, skewed oval to asymmetrical with convex outer side, sessile , adaxial , arising between secondary laterals
a family or genus with only one taxonomi: a family or genus with only one taxonomic component; axes or populations that are phenotypically consistent. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a monosporangium formed by an oblique di: a monosporangium formed by an oblique division of a cell by a curved wall . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
growing within a plant; cf. semi-endophy: growing within a plant; cf. semi-endophytic ; epiphytic (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
in crustose algae, the uppermost layer;: in crustose algae , the uppermost layer; also a surface tissue produced outwardly by an intercalary meristem . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
many branches (3 or more) that arise in: many branches (3 or more) that arise in all directions from a main stalk and are in a circle around an axis . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
pattern of cells developing within origi: pattern of cells developing within original spore wall (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
pigmented membranous vesicles within pla: pigmented membranous vesicles within plastids; the site of photosynthesis. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
spores in 3n fronds of the ceramiaceae t: spores in 3n fronds of the ceramiaceae that grow into the next generation ; not homologous to tetrasporangia. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
term used when data apply to both types: term used when data apply to both types of conceptacle (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the calcified segments between the joint: the calcified segments between the joints of an articulated coralline alga separated by noncalcified tissue. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
with cells laterally aligned in curving: with cells laterally aligned in curving rows (fig.97b) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
with reproductive bodies borne at same l: with reproductive bodies borne at same level (fig.17c) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
<p><strong>intercalary, small chambered,: intercalary , small chambered, hollow antheridia and intercalary oogonia in series  of 2 or more; both on side branches and on same individual; both much wider than axis
<p>distinct main axis with 2nd and 3rd o: distinct main axis with 2nd and 3rd order short branches, pinnate , opposite and equal, long and short branches alternating, giving a feathery appearance; ultimate branches often in one plane
<p>intercalary unilocs or plurilocs in r: intercalary unilocs or plurilocs in rows, on same thalli , up to 20 in a row ; if terminating into hair -like end, cell not tapering; Helgoland: mostly only unilocs; in June-July also plurilocs
branches only arising on one side (longi: branches only arising on one side (longitudinally) along the main axis - i.e. either originating on or all turned towards one side (cf. bilateral , secund & unilateral ) (source: Algaebase (2021-05)).
decay during burial results in progressi: decay during burial results in progressive separation of a thallus to form moss-like carpets in fucoid algae . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
joint in a segmented axis; end-walls bet: joint in a segmented axis ; end-walls between contiguous cells of a filament (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
organisms whose cells lack distinct memb: organisms whose cells lack distinct membrane-bounded nuclei and chloroplasts in contrast to eukaryotic cells. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the presence of separate male and female: the presence of separate male and female conceptacles in the same receptacle and thallus (see hermaphrodite ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the taxonomic system of naming or the us: the taxonomic system of naming or the use of rules to correctly determine the scientific name of an organism. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
when the haploid phase is prominent and: when the haploid phase is prominent and the diploid phase consists only of the zygote cell. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p>no opposite branches but irregular, o: no opposite branches but irregular, often 2-5 laterals arising on top of the other from adjacent cells; laterals often in nearly right angles to main axis , upper part with only short branches
<p>with <strong>narrow </strong>bases, s: with narrow bases, slightly assymetrical, elongated egg -shaped and pointed, sessile , adaxial arranged in series, normally without intercalated diverging vegetative branchlets
a usually delicate median line of cells,: a usually delicate median line of cells, with the blade being thicker through this region than on either side. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
bent like a bow; spermatangial systems i: bent like a bow; spermatangial systems in melobesioideae (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
<p>plurilocs stalked, oblong and attenua: plurilocs stalked, oblong and attenuate (silique), broadest at center, often enlongating into a few-celled false hair ; unilocs sessile egg -shaped, rare, normally on same thallus with plurilocs
a unicellular, usually planktonic but so: a unicellular , usually planktonic but sometimes benthic , organism with 2 flagella (as in the phylum dinophyta). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
carpogonial branch and auxiliary cell in: carpogonial branch and auxiliary cell in close proximity in branching system. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
linear polysaccharide made up of glucose: linear polysaccharide made up of glucose residues joined by b, 1, 4 linkages. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
the remains of calcareous red seaweeds (: the remains of calcareous red seaweeds (coralline rhodophytes); also a collective name for coralline red algae . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p><strong>sparsely </strong>branched fi: sparsely branched filaments, esp. in inner parts; short, hook-shaped side branches may clasp outwardly growing filaments, esp.  in young individuals
<p>plurilocs stalked, elongate, broadest: plurilocs stalked, elongate, broadest below its center, no false hair ; unilocs sessile egg -shaped, rather present in spring; both in series often inserted unilaterally on upper side of branches
a type of branching in which 2 branches: a type of branching in which 2 branches occur at a node , with these being opposite or about 180° to each other. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a type of growth in which secondary axes: a type of growth in which secondary axes arise behind and are subsidiary to a main axis that grows indefinitely. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
cell division where the protoplast divid: cell division where the protoplast divides into 2 or more spherical multinucleate bodies within the mother cell. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
fat soluble, green, photosynthetic pigme: fat soluble, green, photosynthetic pigments, consisting of closed tetrapyrrols with magnesium. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
limp. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987: limp. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
non-motile asexual spore, with a wall in: non-motile asexual spore , with a wall incorporated in that of the parent cell . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
spherical growths of free-living non-gen: spherical growths of free-living non-geniculate coralline red algae that form around pebbles or shell fragments. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
thallus texture rough but slightly shiny: thallus texture rough but slightly shiny; cf. glossy , matt (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
the carposporophyte and accessory envelo: the carposporophyte and accessory enveloping tissue (pericarp ) of the female gametophyte in the florideophyceae. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the storage product of most chrysophyta,: the storage product of most chrysophyta, consisting largely of β-1, 3- glucopyranoside units. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
<p>&nbsp;plurilocs unknown; <strong>unil: plurilocs unknown; unilocs long oval, common, at lateral   base of cushion, and embedded in ± colourless paraphyses
a doubtful name, to be discarded accordi: a doubtful name, to be discarded according to the international code of botanical nomenclature . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a shape that is intermediate between obl: a shape that is intermediate between oblong and ellipse when viewed in 2 dimensions (i.e., a 2-dimensional term). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an area where cell division is continual: an area where cell division is continual; also a localized region functioning to expand a thallus (see meristem ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the capacity of an organism to change it: the capacity of an organism to change its form in response to varying environmental conditions. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
when branches originate from small lenti: when branches originate from small lenticular segments of the apical cells (in sphacelariales). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a partition of primary wall material, us: a partition of primary wall material, usually formed during cell division to separate newly formed daughter cells. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a taxonomic term referring to more than: a taxonomic term referring to more than one name published at the same time by the same author for the same taxon . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
contents of a sporangium destined to div: contents of a sporangium destined to divide into four spores (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
group of initials, especially those init: group of initials, especially those initiating a conceptacle (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
hole(s) in a conceptacle roof through wh: hole(s) in a conceptacle roof through which sporangia escape (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
one or more short gene sequences taken f: one or more short gene sequences taken from a standardized portion of the genome and used to identify an organism. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
pigments with oxygen-free, unsaturated h: pigments with oxygen-free, unsaturated hydrocarbons that are fat soluble and reflect yellow, orange, or red light. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
roof of multiporate conceptacle that con: roof of multiporate conceptacle that contains the pore plugs (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
specialized pod-like branchlet bearing s: specialized pod-like branchlet bearing series of tetrasporangia (e.g. fig. 85d). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
the large-chain ribulose 1, 5 bisphospha: the large-chain ribulose 1, 5 bisphosphate carboxylase gene sequence that is part of the chloroplast dna molecule. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a group of sterile cells or filaments fo: a group of sterile cells or filaments forming a protective envelope around a reproductive structure (see indusium). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a parasite that is unrelated to its host: a parasite that is unrelated to its host ; cf. adelphoparasite (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a single-celled asexual structure in whi: a single-celled asexual structure in which the entire spore is formed inside the vegetative cell (e.g., tribonema). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a sporangium with relatively large locul: a sporangium with relatively large locules, producing the larger of two differently-sized spores. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
an adjective referring to nuclear cytolo: an adjective referring to nuclear cytological characteristics of a cell, especially with regard to the chromosomes. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an initial terminating a filament; cf. s: an initial terminating a filament ; cf. subepithallial initial (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
cells containing distinctive calcium car: cells containing distinctive calcium carbonate crystals; also intracellular biogenetic amorphous calcium carbonate. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
division of tetrasporangium in which all: division of tetrasporangium in which all radial walls are at 120° to each other. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
lower cell (also called foot cell) forme: lower cell (also called foot cell ) formed by division of auxiliary cell into two. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
orange-yellow isoprenoid polyene pigment: orange-yellow isoprenoid polyene pigments containing carbon and hydrogen, present in phaeoplasts. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
stalked. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1: stalked. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
the product of fusion of two gametes, be: the product of fusion of two gametes, before it has undergone mitosis or meiosis . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a cluster of filaments that produces car: a cluster of filaments that produces carpogonial branches or auxiliary cells as in some members of the gigartinales. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a fertile area where gametangia or spora: a fertile area where gametangia or sporangia occur in some brown (e.g., fucales) and red algae (e.g., corallinales). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a group of individuals united in a commo: a group of individuals united in a common life, but not forming a single organism. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a tissue of thin-walled, more or less is: a tissue of thin-walled, more or less isodiametric cells, derived by division in different planes. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
carotenoid pigments that are fat soluble: carotenoid pigments that are fat soluble; reflect yellow, orange, or red light; and contain oxygenated hydrocarbons. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
fusion of main and lateral axes over a n: fusion of main and lateral axes over a number of segments (e.g. in pterosiphonia). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
thallus surface smooth and dull, not shi: thallus surface smooth and dull, not shiny; cf. glossy , grainy (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
with only one sex in any one individual: with only one sex in any one individual or within one reproductive structure (e.g. a conceptacle ). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a group of meristematic cells from which: a group of meristematic cells from which a conceptacle develops (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a structure in which a monospore arises: a structure in which a monospore arises {see also lenticular monosporangium above). (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
conceptacle in which the roof is flush w: conceptacle in which the roof is flush with the thallus surface (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
growing attached to an inorganic substra: growing attached to an inorganic substratum (rock, stones etc.) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
in characeae, a miniature \"crown\" at t: in characeae, a miniature "crown" at the upper end of an oogonium ; the end cells that enclose and cover the oogonium . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
leaf-like. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
a distinctive fringe zone which is somet: a distinctive fringe zone which is sometimes characteristic of the region just below the eulittoral . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a life history in which the haploid game: a life history in which the haploid gametophytic thallus is structurally identical to the diploid sporophytic thallus. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a parasite that is closely related to it: a parasite that is closely related to its host ; cf. alloparasite (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
coalescent; e.g. of branch systems in li: coalescent; e.g. of branch systems in lithothamnion corallioides (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
elongate, slender cells or filaments der: elongate, slender cells or filaments derived laterally from medullary cells (in larger brown algae ). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
in the characeae, a group of tiny cells: in the characeae, a group of tiny cells at the tip of a branchlet formed by reduction of the end cell and bract cells. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
of a life history, consisting of reprodu: of a life history , consisting of reproductive phases each with a similar morphology . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
part seawater and part freshwater (i.e.,: part seawater and part freshwater (i.e., diluted seawater); also refers to stable low salinities as in the baltic sea. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
<p>pairs of opposite branches arising fr: pairs of opposite branches arising from neighbouring cells in storey-like manner, resulting in a whorl -like pattern (creating ‘nodes’ and ‘internodes’),  laterals tapering towards the tip
club-shaped. (source: Womersley, H. B. S: club-shaped. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
forming 2 unequal dichotomies or having: forming 2 unequal dichotomies or having 2 equal branches at branch point, with one being derived from a lateral branch . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
laterally aligned contiguous cells of er: laterally aligned contiguous cells of erect or cortical filaments (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
spore produced by the blade phase where: spore produced by the blade phase where the ploidy level and development are unknown. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
structure that becomes detached from par: structure that becomes detached from parent plant and gives rise to a new individual. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
a cluster or tuft ofbranches (branchlets: a cluster or tuft ofbranches (branchlets) that arise near the same area on an axis ; also, a dense cluster of erect axes. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a flat, lateral protrusion of an interge: a flat, lateral protrusion of an intergeniculum ; in corallinoideae (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a general term for carotenes and xanthop: a general term for carotenes and xanthophyll pigments, which are long hydrocarbon molecules with terminal benzene rings. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a group that includes a most recent comm: a group that includes a most recent common ancestor plus only some of its descendants. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
branching many times from a terminal poi: branching many times from a terminal point or area; a condition in which an axis branches in many lobes of equal status. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
cell in which the haploid nucleus is dis: cell in which the haploid nucleus is disposed of during post-fertilization development (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
nomen conservandum, or a name conserved: nomen conservandum, or a name conserved according to the international code of botanical nomenclature . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
thallus type composed of medulla and cor: thallus type composed of medulla and cortex (fig. 2c); cf dimerous (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
tube-like extension of spermatangial (ra: tube-like extension of spermatangial (rarely tetrasporangial) pore (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a latin phrase that indicates the unders: a latin phrase that indicates the understanding of one author represents only part of what the original author described. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a male gamete . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
in brown algae, hairs that possess plast: in brown algae , hairs that possess plastids, terminate filament tips only, and lack a distinct basal meristem and sheath . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
small pit or flask-shaped structures in: small pit or flask-shaped structures in brown algal blades, which often contain sterile hairs that extend to the surface. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
sporangium containing more than 8 spores: sporangium containing more than 8 spores, usually developing from a multinucleate cell. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
the larger, conspicuous, phase in the li: the larger, conspicuous, phase in the life history of an organism, as contrasted with the microthallus . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
within a cell. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
having a cortex (source: Womersley, H. B: having a cortex (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
nonmotile spores produced in parent cell: nonmotile spores produced in parent cells that develop the same shape as the parent cell at an early stage before release. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
of a life history, consisting of reprodu: of a life history , consisting of reproductive phases each within a different morphology . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
segmented, jointed, or appearing as segm: segmented, jointed, or appearing as segmented, flexible branches (e.g., some members of the red algal order corallinales). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a cell cut off by a pericentral cell (e.g., polysiphonia); also used to describe the epithelium in crustose coralline alga . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a partial parasite that obtains some of: a partial parasite that obtains some of its nourishment from its host but also by photosynthesis (e.g., vertebrata lanosa). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
an orange-red pigmented spot found in so: an orange-red pigmented spot found in some motile cells; it contains hematochrome and is usually associated with a plastid . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
embedded within. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
like a membrane. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
parallel or radiating thickenings or dif: parallel or radiating thickenings or differentiated cell rows in blade or flattened axis . (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
reproduction of the same phase of the (p: reproduction of the same phase of the (potential) life history by means of asexual spores, or propagules. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
ring of axes that form a partial enclosu: ring of axes that form a partial enclosure around reproductive structure (e.g. fig. 14c). (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
a forward projecting extension of an int: a forward projecting extension of an intergeniculum ; in corallinoideae (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
mucilaginous substance blocking (usually: mucilaginous substance blocking (usually multiporate) conceptacle pore (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
on one side only. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
sporangium that contains eight spores at: sporangium that contains eight spores at maturity, usually derived from a binucleate cell. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
a well-defined group of individual cells: a well-defined group of individual cells, usually with a distinct morphology held together by a common mucilage (see colony ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
any duplicate (part of a single gatherin: any duplicate (part of a single gathering made by a collector at one time) of the holotype . (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
conducting elements in the phloem of vas: conducting elements in the phloem of vascular plants; similar elements occur in the stipes of laminariales. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
oxygenated hydrocarbons derived from the: oxygenated hydrocarbons derived from the carotenes, found in plastids as accessory photosynthetic pigments. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
thallus construction of free or consolid: thallus construction of free or consolidated filaments but lacking intercalary longitudinal cell divisions. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
thick white disc shed by some conceptacl: thick white disc shed by some conceptacles; in melobesioideae; cf. veil (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a general term used for outgrowths such: a general term used for outgrowths such as lamellae, protuberances, etc. (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a sporangium that forms more than 4 spor: a sporangium that forms more than 4 spores, with at least the first division being mitotic; thus, it is not a tetrasporangium . (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
borne on a pedicel. (source: Womersley,: borne on a pedicel . (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
branched, usually relatively robust, att: branched, usually relatively robust , attachment organs (especially in the laminariales and certain fucales). (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
elongated, multinucleated, longitudinal: elongated, multinucleated, longitudinal conducting elements in some kelps and members of the phyllariaceae ( see allelocysts ). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
